title: BadGraph: A Backdoor Attack Against Latent Diffusion Model for Text-Guided Graph Generation
summary: This paper introduces BadGraph, a novel backdoor attack method targeting latent diffusion models used for text-guided graph generation. BadGraph leverages textual triggers to subtly poison training data, embedding hidden vulnerabilities that compel the model to generate attacker-specified subgraphs during inference when these triggers are present, while maintaining normal performance on clean inputs. The study demonstrates the attack's high effectiveness and stealth across multiple datasets, revealing significant security vulnerabilities in these models with critical implications for applications like drug discovery.

title: Predicting Protein-Nucleic Acid Flexibility Using Persistent Sheaf Laplacians
summary: This paper introduces the Persistent Sheaf Laplacian (PSL) framework for accurately predicting the flexibility of protein-nucleic acid complexes, characterized by atomic B-factors. PSL integrates multiscale analysis, algebraic topology, and sheaf theory to overcome limitations of traditional models, demonstrating up to a 21% improvement in B-factor prediction accuracy on diverse datasets. These findings highlight PSL's potential for enhanced understanding of biomolecular dynamics relevant to drug discovery and mutation analysis.

title: Acoustic Emission Cascade Predicting Progression to Failure of Rock and Bone
summary: This research identifies a universal 'Acoustic Emission (AE) cascade' phenomenon preceding failure in quasi-brittle materials like rock and bone, demonstrating its potential for real-time failure prediction. The study shows that this cascade, arising from a specific power-law coupling, provides a critical 30-70 second warning for impending skull fracture in simulated neurosurgical contexts. This predictive capability could significantly enhance patient safety by allowing for timely remedial action.

title: ACS-SegNet: An Attention-Based CNN-SegFormer Segmentation Network for Tissue Segmentation in Histopathology
summary: This paper introduces ACS-SegNet, a novel attention-based dual-encoder segmentation network that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Vision Transformers (ViTs) for semantic tissue segmentation in histopathological images. The model demonstrates superior performance on two publicly available datasets, GCPS and PUMA, consistently outperforming state-of-the-art and baseline methods with high μIoU and μDice scores.

title: Empathic Prompting: Non-Verbal Context Integration for Multimodal LLM Conversations
summary: Empathic Prompting is a novel multimodal framework designed to enrich Large Language Model (LLM) conversations by integrating implicit non-verbal emotional context, captured via facial expression recognition, directly into prompts. This unobtrusive system has demonstrated consistent integration of emotional cues into coherent LLM outputs, leading to improved conversational fluidity and alignment.

title: Automated Extraction of Fluoropyrimidine Treatment and Treatment-Related Toxicities from Clinical Notes Using Natural Language Processing
summary: This paper developed and evaluated various Natural Language Processing (NLP) methods to automatically extract fluoropyrimidine treatment and associated toxicity information from oncology clinical notes. The study found that Large Language Model (LLM)-based approaches, particularly with error-analysis prompting, achieved superior performance (F1=1.000) compared to traditional machine learning, deep learning, and rule-based methods. This highlights the potential of LLMs to support oncology research and pharmacovigilance by efficiently extracting crucial clinical data.

title: Optimizing Clinical Fall Risk Prediction: A Data-Driven Integration of EHR Variables with the Johns Hopkins Fall Risk Assessment Tool
summary: This study optimized clinical fall risk prediction by integrating Electronic Health Record (EHR) variables with the Johns Hopkins Fall Risk Assessment Tool (JHFRAT) using a data-driven constrained score optimization (CSO) model. The CSO model significantly improved predictive performance (AUC-ROC=0.91) compared to the standard JHFRAT (AUC-ROC=0.86), offering a robust and interpretable method for enhancing inpatient fall prevention.
keywords: Johns Hopkins Fall Risk Assessment Tool

title: GRACE: GRaph-based Addiction Care prEdiction
summary: This paper introduces GRACE, a novel Graph Neural Network (GNN) framework, designed to automate the critical clinical decision of determining the appropriate locus of care for addiction patients. By formalizing this as a structured learning problem and employing extensive feature engineering with an unbiased meta-graph approach, GRACE effectively mitigates severe class imbalance in addiction datasets. The framework demonstrates significant improvements, achieving an 11-35% increase in the F1 score for the minority class over competitive baselines on real-world data.

title: xTime: Extreme Event Prediction with Hierarchical Knowledge Distillation and Expert Fusion
summary: This paper introduces xTime, a novel framework designed for accurate forecasting of extreme events in real-world time series, addressing the limitations of existing models that often struggle with data imbalance and the neglect of precursor information. xTime employs hierarchical knowledge distillation to leverage insights from lower-rarity events and incorporates a mixture of experts mechanism for dynamic output fusion across different rarity levels. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in extreme event forecasting accuracy, ranging from 3% to 78%.

title: Better Tokens for Better 3D: Advancing Vision-Language Modeling in 3D Medical Imaging
summary: BTB3D (Better Tokens for Better 3D) introduces a novel causal convolutional encoder-decoder to advance vision-language modeling in 3D medical imaging, particularly for high-resolution CT volumes. By generating compact, frequency-aware volumetric tokens through a three-stage training curriculum, it achieves new state-of-the-art results in automated report generation and text-to-CT synthesis, demonstrating the crucial role of precise 3D tokenization.

title: Deep Learning in Dental Image Analysis: A Systematic Review of Datasets, Methodologies, and Emerging Challenges
summary: This systematic review comprehensively analyzes 260 deep learning (DL) studies in dental image analysis (DIA), focusing on publicly available datasets and DL-based algorithms. It addresses the inherent challenges in manual dental image interpretation by summarizing recent progress in DL, categorizing models by task, and discussing methodologies, performance, and future directions. The paper aims to provide a valuable and systematic reference for researchers in the field of computer-aided dental diagnosis and treatment.

title: Equitable Survival Prediction: A Fairness-Aware Survival Modeling (FASM) Approach
summary: This paper introduces Fairness-Aware Survival Modeling (FASM), an approach designed to mitigate algorithmic bias in survival predictions, specifically addressing disparities in both intra-group and cross-group risk rankings over time. Applied to SEER breast cancer data, FASM significantly enhances fairness while maintaining prediction accuracy, demonstrating stable improvements over a 10-year period, particularly in the mid-term.

title: PSO-XAI: A PSO-Enhanced Explainable AI Framework for Reliable Breast Cancer Detection
summary: This research introduces PSO-XAI, an integrated framework leveraging customized Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) for intelligent feature selection in breast cancer detection. Evaluated across 29 diverse machine learning models, the framework achieved a superior performance of 99.1% across all metrics while providing transparent, model-agnostic explanations through explainable AI methods. This approach offers a robust, trustworthy, and clinically meaningful solution for early and accurate breast cancer diagnosis.

title: The Dog the Cat Chased Stumped the Model: Measuring When Language Models Abandon Structure for Shortcuts
summary: This paper introduces CenterBench, a novel dataset designed to evaluate language models' ability to distinguish true structural understanding from mere semantic pattern matching in complex, center-embedded sentences. By comparing performance on syntactically identical but semantically plausible versus implausible sentences, the study quantifies that models increasingly abandon structural analysis for semantic shortcuts as linguistic complexity grows. The findings highlight a critical limitation in current language models, particularly concerning their reliable interpretation of causal relationships independent of semantic coherence.

title: Fitness inference tested by in silico population genetics
summary: This research investigates the feasibility of inferring fitness parameters and genotype fitness order from genomic data in populations evolving under natural selection, mutation, and recombination. Through *in silico* simulations, the authors delineate specific parameter ranges where such inference is possible and where it is not, thereby providing a crucial framework for assessing the utility of population-wide, whole-genome, time-stratified data for fitness inference. The study also identifies relevant biological systems, including human pathogens, where this framework can be applied.

title: On Multiple Robustness of Proximal Dynamic Treatment Regimes
summary: This research introduces a novel methodology for estimating optimal dynamic treatment regimes (DTRs) from observational data, specifically addressing the critical challenge where the standard unconfoundedness assumption fails due to unmeasured confounding. Utilizing a proximal causal inference framework, the paper proposes nonparametric identification methods, establishes semiparametric efficiency bounds, and develops a (K+1)-robust estimation approach for DTRs, with implications for precision medicine.

title: MolBridge: Atom-Level Joint Graph Refinement for Robust Drug-Drug Interaction Event Prediction
summary: MolBridge is a novel atom-level joint graph refinement framework designed for robust drug-drug interaction (DDI) event prediction. It addresses the limitations of existing methods by constructing a joint graph from paired drug molecules, enabling direct modeling of fine-grained inter-drug associations and overcoming over-smoothing through a structure consistency module, leading to superior performance across diverse DDI types and scenarios.

title: Dynamic Weight Adjustment for Knowledge Distillation: Leveraging Vision Transformer for High-Accuracy Lung Cancer Detection and Real-Time Deployment
summary: This paper introduces FuzzyDistillViT-MobileNet, a novel model for lung cancer classification that utilizes dynamic fuzzy logic-driven knowledge distillation (KD) to address uncertainty and enhance diagnostic accuracy. By dynamically adjusting distillation weights and employing advanced image preprocessing and model selection techniques, the model achieves high accuracy and robustness across both histopathological and CT-scan lung cancer datasets. The approach significantly improves the student model's ability to focus on high-confidence regions and generalize effectively.

title: Identification and Debiased Learning of Causal Effects with General Instrumental Variables
summary: This paper introduces a general nonparametric framework for identifying and learning causal effects using multi-categorical or continuous instrumental variables (IVs). It proposes an additive IV framework to identify mean potential outcomes and the average treatment effect (ATE), employing semiparametric theory and debiased machine learning to construct consistent and asymptotically normal estimators, with extensions to complex data structures.

title: Contrast-enhanced X-ray imaging of articular cartilage: reliability of a cationic contrast agent in combination with high-resolution peripheral quantitative computed tomography system
summary: This study investigated the reliability of combining a cationic contrast agent (CA4+) with high-resolution peripheral quantitative computed tomography (HR-pQCT) to quantify proteoglycan content in articular cartilage. It successfully demonstrated significant correlations between the enhanced radiopacity, directly attributable to proteoglycan levels, and the viscoelastic mechanical properties of healthy bovine articular cartilage, suggesting a promising tool for early detection of cartilage degeneration.

title: Bias by Design? How Data Practices Shape Fairness in AI Healthcare Systems
summary: This paper addresses the critical issue of biased training data hindering the integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into clinical practice. Drawing insights from the AI4HealthyAging project, the authors identify historical, representation, and measurement biases across various demographic and clinical variables during clinical data collection. They conclude by offering practical recommendations to enhance the fairness and robustness of AI healthcare systems, aiming to guide future projects in developing more equitable solutions.

title: Enhancing Security in Deep Reinforcement Learning: A Comprehensive Survey on Adversarial Attacks and Defenses
summary: This paper provides a comprehensive survey on adversarial attacks and defense mechanisms in Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL), emphasizing their critical importance for security-sensitive applications like autonomous driving and smart healthcare. It introduces a novel classification framework for attacks, details various perturbation methods targeting different DRL components, and systematically reviews current robustness training strategies, highlighting their advantages and shortcomings.
domains: Drug Discovery (indirectly, if DRL is used in optimization)

title: DB-FGA-Net: Dual Backbone Frequency Gated Attention Network for Multi-Class Classification with Grad-CAM Interpretability
summary: DB-FGA-Net is a novel deep learning model for multi-class brain tumor classification that integrates VGG16 and Xception backbones with a Frequency-Gated Attention (FGA) Block. It achieves state-of-the-art accuracy across multiple classification settings (up to 99.85% for 2-class) without requiring data augmentation, enhancing robustness and generalization. The model also incorporates Grad-CAM for interpretability and a GUI for real-time clinical deployment.

title: Classical Feature Embeddings Help in BERT-Based Human Mobility Prediction
summary: This paper introduces STaBERT, a novel BERT-based model designed to significantly improve human mobility prediction by integrating derived temporal descriptors and Points of Interest (POI) embeddings. By creating a unified, semantically enriched representation of movement, STaBERT addresses the limitations of existing models that underutilize rich contextual information, demonstrating substantial gains in prediction accuracy across single- and multi-city scenarios.

title: Tri-Modal Severity Fused Diagnosis across Depression and Post-traumatic Stress Disorders
summary: This paper introduces a unified tri-modal framework for severity-aware, cross-disorder diagnosis of depression (5 classes) and PTSD (3 classes) by fusing interview text, audio, and facial signals. Utilizing advanced features like transformer embeddings and action units, the approach employs a calibrated late fusion classifier to output graded severities and feature-level attributions. The fused model demonstrates superior robustness and utility over unimodal baselines, particularly for PTSD, offering enhanced decision support for clinicians.

title: Towards Objective Obstetric Ultrasound Assessment: Contrastive Representation Learning for Fetal Movement Detection
summary: This paper introduces Contrastive Ultrasound Video Representation Learning (CURL), a novel self-supervised learning framework for objective and accurate fetal movement (FM) detection from extended ultrasound videos. By employing a dual-contrastive loss and a task-specific sampling strategy, CURL learns robust motion representations, achieving a sensitivity of 78.01% and an AUROC of 81.60% on an in-house dataset. The framework holds significant potential for enhancing prenatal health monitoring and clinical decision-making by providing an objective assessment of fetal activity.

title: Assessing the Feasibility of Early Cancer Detection Using Routine Laboratory Data: An Evaluation of Machine Learning Approaches on an Imbalanced Dataset
summary: This study evaluated the feasibility of early cancer detection in dogs using machine learning on routine, low-cost laboratory data from an imbalanced dataset. It revealed that while a statistically detectable cancer signal exists (AUROC = 0.815), the optimal model delivered poor clinical classification performance (F1-score = 0.25, PPV = 0.15) driven by non-specific markers, rendering it unsuitable for reliable diagnostic use in isolation. The work establishes a performance ceiling for this data modality and emphasizes the need for multi-modal data integration for future progress.

title: A Structured Review and Quantitative Profiling of Public Brain MRI Datasets for Foundation Model Development
summary: This study systematically reviews 54 public brain MRI datasets, encompassing over 538,031 images, to assess their suitability for foundation model development. It uncovers significant data imbalances, image-level heterogeneity, and demonstrates that standard preprocessing, while improving within-dataset consistency, leaves substantial inter-dataset bias and covariate shift, necessitating advanced domain-adaptive strategies for generalizable models.

title: Understanding Mechanistic Role of Structural and Functional Connectivity in Tau Propagation Through Multi-Layer Modeling
summary: This research utilizes a multi-layer graph diffusion model with extensive longitudinal neuroimaging data to elucidate the interacting roles of structural (SC) and functional connectivity (FC) in tau propagation in Alzheimer's disease (AD). The study reveals a regionally asymmetric contribution of SC and FC to tau spread, with their relative dominance shifting across disease stages, and links these patterns to specific AD-associated gene expression and non-modifiable risk factors.

title: Why Prototypes Collapse: Diagnosing and Preventing Partial Collapse in Prototypical Self-Supervised Learning
summary: This paper diagnoses partial prototype collapse in prototypical self-supervised learning (SSL) methods as a consequence of the joint optimization of encoders and prototypes, which encourages shortcut learning. It introduces a novel fully decoupled training strategy that models prototypes as a Gaussian mixture updated independently of the encoder, effectively eliminating collapse, yielding consistently diverse prototypes, and achieving stronger downstream performance without explicit regularization.

title: Extending machine learning model for implicit solvation to free energy calculations
summary: This paper introduces Lambda Solvation Neural Network (LSNN), a novel Graph Neural Network (GNN)-based implicit solvent model designed to overcome the accuracy limitations of traditional implicit models and existing machine learning methods for free energy calculations. By training on both force-matching and the derivatives of alchemical variables, LSNN achieves solvation free energy predictions with accuracy comparable to explicit-solvent simulations while offering significant computational speedup. This methodology establishes a robust framework crucial for drug discovery applications.

title: ShapeX: Shapelet-Driven Post Hoc Explanations for Time Series Classification Models
summary: ShapeX is an innovative framework addressing the limitations of existing post-hoc time series explanation methods by focusing on shapelet-driven segments rather than individual timesteps. It leverages the Shapelet Describe-and-Detect (SDD) framework and Shapley values to identify salient subsequences, providing explanations that reveal causal relationships instead of mere correlations. Experimental results confirm ShapeX's superior performance in precision and causal fidelity compared to current approaches.

title: Ask What Your Country Can Do For You: Towards a Public Red Teaming Model
summary: This paper proposes a novel approach called "cooperative public AI red-teaming exercises" to address the critical "responsibility gap" in evaluating AI systems, especially those deployed in high-stakes sectors like healthcare. It argues that current adversarial evaluation methods are insufficient for sophisticated AI and presents early positive results from pilot implementations (CAMLIS 2024, NIST ARIA, Singapore IMDA), demonstrating the model's effectiveness and scalability in rigorously assessing AI risks and vulnerabilities.

title: Endogenous Aggregation of Multiple Data Envelopment Analysis Scores for Large Data Sets
summary: This paper introduces a novel Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) approach designed for dynamic and multi-dimensional efficiency evaluation in large organizational datasets. It proposes two regularized DEA models, SBM and GP-SBM, which integrate both desirable and undesirable outputs and enhance discriminatory power through regularization. The methods were validated for computational efficiency and applied to a case study of Canadian hospitals, demonstrating superior performance in capturing input/output correlations compared to conventional benchmarking.

title: BrainPuzzle: Hybrid Physics and Data-Driven Reconstruction for Transcranial Ultrasound Tomography
summary: BrainPuzzle introduces a novel hybrid physics- and data-driven framework to achieve accurate speed-of-sound (SoS) map reconstruction for transcranial ultrasound tomography, addressing limitations of traditional methods. It combines reverse time migration for robust structural fragment generation with a transformer-based super-resolution network to fuse these fragments from sparse, multi-angle acquisitions. Experiments on synthetic datasets demonstrate its superior SoS reconstruction accuracy and image completeness, overcoming challenges posed by skull aberrations and sparse data.

title: AI Pose Analysis and Kinematic Profiling of Range-of-Motion Variations in Resistance Training
summary: This study introduces an AI-based pose estimation pipeline for precise kinematic quantification of resistance training, analyzing lengthened partial (pROM) and full range-of-motion (fROM) exercises. It reveals that pROM repetitions are characterized by smaller ROM and shorter durations, especially in the eccentric phase, with participant-level differences being the primary driver of variation. The research underscores the potential of AI-driven methods to advance exercise science and optimize resistance training prescription by providing objective insights into execution dynamics and consistency.

title: Improving Predictive Confidence in Medical Imaging via Online Label Smoothing
summary: This paper introduces Online Label Smoothing (OLS), a dynamic method to improve predictive confidence and accuracy in medical image classification by adjusting soft labels based on the model's own prediction patterns during training. OLS consistently enhances Top-1 and Top-5 accuracy, fosters better feature representation, and improves calibration across various architectures on the RadImageNet dataset, making AI systems more trustworthy in healthcare.

title: Beyond MedQA: Towards Real-world Clinical Decision Making in the Era of LLMs
summary: This paper proposes a unifying paradigm to evaluate large language models (LLMs) for clinical use, arguing that current benchmarks like MedQA oversimplify real-world clinical decision-making. It characterizes clinical tasks along two dimensions, 'Clinical Backgrounds' and 'Clinical Questions,' to better reflect increasing complexity, reviews existing methods, and extends evaluation metrics beyond accuracy to include efficiency and explainability.

title: RELATE: A Schema-Agnostic Perceiver Encoder for Multimodal Relational Graphs
summary: This paper introduces RELATE, a schema-agnostic Perceiver encoder designed for multimodal relational graphs, specifically addressing the scalability and parameter sharing limitations of existing schema-specific GNNs in domains like healthcare. RELATE utilizes shared modality-specific encoders for diverse attributes (categorical, numerical, textual, temporal) and a Perceiver-style cross-attention module to generate fixed-size, permutation-invariant node representations. It achieves performance within 3% of schema-specific encoders while drastically reducing parameter counts by up to 5x, enabling multi-dataset pretraining and paving the way for foundation models for relational graph data.

title: Drug-disease networks and drug repurposing
summary: This paper presents a novel drug-disease network, compiled from diverse data sources, to enhance drug repurposing efforts. By applying network-based link prediction methods like graph embedding and network model fitting, the study achieved impressive accuracy (AUC > 0.95) in identifying new drug-disease associations, significantly outperforming previous computational approaches.

title: FINDER: Feature Inference on Noisy Datasets using Eigenspace Residuals
summary:
''Noisy'' datasets (regimes with low signal to noise ratios, small sample
sizes, faulty data collection, etc) remain a key research frontier for
classification methods with both theoretical and practical implications. We
introduce FINDER, a rigorous framework for analyzing generic classification
pro...

title: Enhancing Diagnostic Accuracy for Urinary Tract Disease through Explainable SHAP-Guided Feature Selection and Classification
summary:
In this paper, we propose an approach to support the diagnosis of urinary
tract diseases, with a focus on bladder cancer, using SHAP (SHapley Additive
exPlanations)-based feature selection to enhance the transparency and
effectiveness of predictive models. Six binary classification scenarios were
de...

title: FairGRPO: Fair Reinforcement Learning for Equitable Clinical Reasoning
summary: This paper introduces Fairness-aware Group Relative Policy Optimization (FairGRPO), a hierarchical reinforcement learning approach designed to mitigate performance disparities of medical AI systems across diverse demographic groups. FairGRPO employs adaptive importance weighting and unsupervised clustering to promote equitable learning, demonstrating a 27.2% reduction in predictive parity and a 12.49% improvement in F1 score across 7 clinical diagnostic datasets spanning 5 modalities, culminating in the release of a fairness-aware clinical VLLM, FairMedGemma-4B.

title: Enabling Granular Subgroup Level Model Evaluations by Generating Synthetic Medical Time Series
summary:
We present a novel framework for leveraging synthetic ICU time-series data
not only to train but also to rigorously and trustworthily evaluate predictive
models, both at the population level and within fine-grained demographic
subgroups. Building on prior diffusion and VAE-based generators (TimeDiff...

title: Compressing Biology: Evaluating the Stable Diffusion VAE for Phenotypic Drug Discovery
summary: This paper systematically evaluates the Stable Diffusion Variational Autoencoder (SD-VAE) for reconstructing high-dimensional Cell Painting microscopy images, a crucial step in phenotypic drug discovery. It demonstrates that SD-VAE effectively preserves phenotypic signals with minimal loss, thereby validating its suitability for microscopy workflows. The study also shows that general-purpose feature extractors like InceptionV3 can perform as well as or better than specialized models in biologically relevant retrieval tasks, simplifying future computational pipelines.
